div.p: Greetings. Musculus was elected by us; but the matter turned out differently before the deacons than we had hoped, since our deacon was elected by them against our will.

The number of votes was so nearly equal that the hands of the voters had to be counted twice, and almost the entire council supported Musculus; but the crowd of common people prevailed, to the great sorrow of all good men. As for us, we warned them very freely about everything, so that I am very glad we have freed our consciences. Therefore, I bear everything more equitably and will conduct everything more courageously from now on than I have so far, so that everyone understands how much depends on them for the peace of the church. And although Musculus's rejection pains me greatly, because I see that this church is not worthy of such a great good, I am nevertheless driven with even greater spirit to do everything manfully. I will indeed make an effort not to do anything imprudently or thoughtlessly; I will bind this man to me as much as I can with gentleness, yet in such a way that I keep him in fear and duty at the same time; for his authority is not so great that I should fear it. Meanwhile, however, because Satan's wiles are varied, I ask that, whatever happens to me, you always recognize me as your own. This in haste.
Regarding the matter of predestination, which is spreading greatly, I will write soon; now there is no time for more. Farewell. November 27, 1552.
To the most illustrious man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the most vigilant leader of the ZÃ¼rich church, his dearest lord and compatriot.
